Author: Michael Kirschner
Article: In addition to the Electronic Product Environmental Assessment Tool (EPEAT) standards I discussed last month, there are other standards bodies vying for your sustainability attention. One, in particular, is TCO Development. This well-known Swedish non-profit has a lengthy history of focusing on improving the sustainability of IT products through the development of standards, and certification and labeling of compliant products. Youâve probably seen the TCO label on monitors and other equipment over the years. TCOâs product scope overlaps with EPEAT to an extent but covers a broader range of data-center equipment as well as other product categories (e.g., projectors and headsets). TCOâs criteria covers many of the same areas as EPEAT and expands in others, like socially and environmentally responsible manufacturing. While there are common criteria across all TCO Certified standards, focusing on TCO Generation 8 for Servers, the following criteria (and more) could â along with the EPEAT criteria identified last month â also be considered for manufacturers of nearly any type of electronic product (or a product that contains electronic components): Most of these are relevant for circularity and all represent solid starting (and maybe end) points. However, I spend a lot of my time dealing with chemicals in electronics and I feel that the industry, and subsequently EPEAT and TCO, focuses on too narrow a set of chemical substances, as well as inadequately addressing the issue of regrettable substitutions. Itâs not just the non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and industry; governments usually fail to deal with the substitution of substances they ban. Halogenated flame retardants are being banned from display, TV and monitor enclosures and their stands in the European Union because they contaminate the recycling stream. For instance, they continue to show up as contaminants in products like kitchen utensils (but less than they used to â so perhaps we are making progress). Both EPEAT and TCO Certified standards ban these halogenated flame retardants as well. Replacing them with phosphorus-based flame retardants â which are the most common alternative technology for most halogenated flame retardant applications â will simply result in the kitchen utensils containing a different, and still unnecessary (and potentially toxic and problematic for this unintended use) flame retardant. Iâm not aware of any studies of phosphorus-based flame retardants in kitchen utensils yet. The rest of the composition of plastic resins intended for use in electronic products merit strong consideration as well. Some of the substances used to meet technical and functional requirements for electronics may also be unnecessary, undesirable, or even dangerous for a kitchen utensil that has to meet food contact material substance requirements. Why, though, would resin composition for an electronic product enclosure also have to meet requirements for food contact material? Doesnât this complicate and narrow the safe design space too much? I think it does. But until the electronics industry invests in a closed-loop recycling and material recovery system that prevents recycled electronic-grade materials from entering material streams destined for food-grade products, this constraint will continue to exist. TCO does deserve credit, though, for going to the next level. For certain categories of substances, namely flame retardants and plasticizers, TCO has produced a list of âsafer alternatives.â Note the use of the term âsaferâ rather than âsafe.â Given the ever-expanding information and insight being developed by toxicologists and other scientists about a wide range of industrial chemicals, saying something is âsafeâ today is dangerous; all we can do is to get better â we canât be perfect today. TCOâs list is, in fact, dynamic and subject to change. TCO and GEC (the organization responsible for EPEAT standards) know what mountain the flag sits atop. And they know how far away we are from that goal. TCO has been at it for 25 years; GEC for over 15. This journey takes time and patience. An interesting webinar will be held on March 18, 2020.
